content: How can I help you today?

Well, I guess I’m here because my wife thought it’d be good for me to talk to someone. To be honest, I’m not sure where to start. Things have been really tough at home with my son, and it feels like I’ve got this weight on my chest all the time. I don’t really know if talking will even help.

It sounds like there’s a lot going on for you, and you’re feeling the heaviness of it all. It’s understandable to feel unsure about whether talking can help, especially when things are tough at home. Maybe we could start by exploring what’s been happening with your son or the weight you’ve been feeling—wherever you feel comfortable opening up. What do you think?

I guess the hardest part is my son’s behavior. He’s been acting out a lot, and no matter what my wife and I try, nothing seems to work. It’s like we’re at a loss, and it’s putting so much strain on our marriage. I’m exhausted, and I don’t even know if I’m doing the right thing as a parent.

It sounds like you’re carrying a lot—trying to support your son, manage the tension with your wife, and questioning yourself as a parent. That’s a lot to deal with, and it makes sense that you’re exhausted. You clearly care deeply about your family, even if that feels challenging right now. How are you managing all of this?

To be honest, I don’t think I’m managing it very well. I feel like I’m stretched so thin, and I’m always on edge. I’ve been shutting down a lot—at work, with my wife, even with myself. It’s like the more I try, the worse it gets, and I’m starting to feel hopeless about it.

Thank you for being open about how you’ve been feeling. It sounds like shutting down has been a way of coping with all the overwhelming stress, but it also seems to be leaving you feeling disconnected—from work, your wife, and even your own sense of hope. You’re in a challenging spot, yet it’s clear that you’re still trying to navigate it and care for the people around you. What do you think it would take to feel even a little less stretched right now?

I'm honestly not sure. I mean, I guess if I had some idea of how to help my son, maybe that would ease some of the pressure. But I just don’t know where to even start with that. And then there’s everything with my wife too—it’s like everything is connected and falling apart at the same time.

It sounds like the uncertainty about how to help your son is adding to the pressure, and as that weighs on you, it’s affecting other parts of your life, including your relationship with your wife. Everything feels tangled together, which makes it even harder to see a starting point. Despite feeling all of this, you care deeply, and that’s clear from how you’re showing up here today. What’s one thing you wish could change right now, even if it feels small?

I guess if I could just figure out how to make things improve even slightly with my son, that might help. I feel like if he was doing better, maybe my wife and I would be less at odds, and the tension at home wouldn’t feel so overwhelming. I just need to know that there’s something I can actually do to make things better.

It sounds like finding a way to support your son feels like the key to easing some of the tension at home and giving you that sense of progress you’ve been searching for. You really want to be able to make a positive difference, not just for him but for your whole family. It takes a lot of courage to share that wish for change, especially when things feel uncertain right now. What steps, if any, have you or your wife tried so far to help him?

We’ve tried talking to him, setting boundaries, different ways of disciplining—but nothing seems to stick. Sometimes he’ll calm down for a day or two, but then it’s back to the same behaviors. It’s like we’re walking on eggshells, and nothing we do makes a real difference.

It’s clear you’ve been giving this your all, trying different approaches and hoping something will click. It must feel incredibly discouraging when those efforts only seem to bring temporary relief before things return to the same cycle. You’re doing your best with what you know, and that persistence shows how much you care. What do you think your son needs most from you right now?

I honestly don’t know. Sometimes I think he might just need more attention or understanding, but other times, it feels like no matter what we do, it’s not enough. It’s hard to tell what’s the right thing to do when everything feels off balance.

It sounds like you’re searching deeply to understand what your son needs, and that uncertainty can make it even harder to feel confident in your efforts. You want to give him the attention and care you think could help, but the challenges and imbalance at home make it hard to know where to focus. It’s a tough situation, and your care for him is undeniable. What would it mean for you to feel more balanced or supported as you figure this out?

It would mean everything, honestly. If I could feel more balanced or supported, I think I’d have more energy and clarity to be there for my son and my family. Right now, I just feel so drained and stuck—I don’t even know where to start to get back to a better place.

It sounds like finding balance and support feels crucial for you to regain the energy and clarity you need to move forward—for your son, your family, and yourself. Feeling drained and stuck can make it hard to see a path forward, but your willingness to reflect on what matters to you shows a strong desire for change. Is there anything else you’d like to share or explore before we think about steps that could help you feel more supported?
I think I’m okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
